text.headline: The Alumni Gymnasium
text.text: The name honours the fund-raising efforts of SDU alumni that helped make construction of the Gym possible. Opened in 1951, it served the University for both sporting and social functions, as well as hosting the annual convocation ceremony, until 1969. The gym continued to serve UPEI for more than 20 years, but fell into disuse during the 1990s, following the opening of the Canada Winter Games/Chi-Wan Young fieldhouse. It was to be incorporated into UPEI’s new Student Centre, but an accidental fire during early construction of the Centre destroyed the Gym in 2001: the two stone torches on the East wall of the Murphy Student Centre were salvaged from the facade of the Alumni Gymnasium. Building Illustration by Sterling Stratton.

text.headline: The Administration (Main) Building
text.text: The oldest building on-campus, and one of two designated Heritage properties at the University, St. Duntan’s University Main Building has been the heart of two academic communities: SDU from 1855 to 1969, and UPEI from 1969 to present. Though less grandiose than first envisioned in the early 1850s, Main Building’s understated but distinguished architecture has stood the test of time: originally the sum total of SDU’s physical plant (apart from a campus farm and some outbuildings), Main Building had to meet all of SDU’s residence, administrative, and teaching needs until 1917, when Dalton Hall opened; it remained a multi-role facility thereafter, housing classrooms, offices, and a men’s residence into the 1960s. UPEI embarked on an extensive but sympathetic renovation in the 1980s, and its numerous offices and lecture halls (as well as the Faculty Lounge) ensure that Main will be a campus focal point for many years to come.

text.headline: Chapel, Dining Hall & Convent
text.text: This combined facility, opened in 1950, was part of a wave of construction undertaken as SDU began to expand in the post-War decade. The Convent housed nuns of the Sisters of St. Martha, who, with “exemplary charity,” provided for decades the cooking, cleaning, and other domestic services needed to sustain the SDU community. During the UPEI era, the building became home to the Music Department in 1975, and the chapel was converted into a recital hall, named in honour of Dr. G. Douglas Steel, former Principal of Prince of Wales College and a keen music education advocate. The lower level of the facility continued to accommodate the campus kitchen and cafeteria until 1991, at which time it was extensively remodelled to house the new School of Nursing, opened in 1992. With Nursing’s move to the new Health Sciences Building in 2012, the lower level of the Steel Building now houses academic offices and the Department of Development and Alumni Engagement

text.headline: Dalton Hall
text.text: Opened in 1919, this is the second-oldest structure on-campus, after Main Building, and is, like Main, a designated Heritage property. The building was named in honour of its chief benefactor, Sir Charles Dalton, a pioneer of the fox-farming industry who became one of the Island’s best-known businessmen, politicians, and philanthropists during the early 1900s. Dalton was also a devout Catholic — he received a Papal knighthood in 1917, the same year construction began on Dalton Hall — so St. Dunstan’s was a fitting object for his charity. The handsome edifice bearing his name — its architecture strongly influenced by the Collegiate Gothic style — served SDU, and then UPEI, as a residence hall until 1972. It was then renovated for classroom and office use, and housed the Home Economics/Family & Nutritional Sciences department for many years. The building is also putative home to one of the best-known figures in SDU and UPEI campus lore, the Ghost of Dalton Hall, claimed to be the spirit of an SDU student who died while in residence

text.headline: Memorial Hall
text.text: Opened in 1947, Memorial Hall was the first product of St. Dunstan’s post-War campus expansion, funded in large measure by an extraordinarily successful fundraising drive in the Island’s Catholic community. The new residence’s name, interestingly, referred not to the dead of the Second World War — a toll which included more than two dozen of the ~400 current and former SDU students who had enlisted to fight — but rather reflected a desire to memorialize the “sacrificial giving” that made its construction possible.  After becoming part of UPEI’s campus in 1969, Memorial Hall remained a men’s residence until 1976, then served briefly as a summer youth hostel, before being renovated and expanded in 1979-1980 to house the departments of Mathematics & Computer Science and Psychology and the Faculty of Education; this project made Memorial the first wheelchair-accessible building on-campus, and also saw the installation of a rooftop observatory dome.

text.headline: Cass Science Hall
text.text: This building, opened by SDU as its “Science Hall” in 1940, is the third-oldest on-campus. Originally housing laboratories and lecture halls for physics, biology, and chemistry, the building was renovated use exclusively as a chemistry building in 1966, after the physics and biology facilities were moved to SDU’s new Duffy Science Centre. The Hall — renamed in memory of pioneering SDU Chemistry professor Father Fred Cass in 1967 — served SDU and then UPEI as a chemistry building until 1996, at which time Chemistry moved to the new KC Irving Building; Cass was then renovated to house the departments of Engineering, Mathematics & Statistics, and Computer Science & Information Technology, and rededicated as the Cass Science Hall in 1997.
